sections.title: Minimizing Estate Taxes
sections.subtitle: Strategies to preserve wealth for your heirs

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Federal and state estate tax exemptions and rates
Gifting strategies and their tax implications
How life insurance fits into estate planning

sections.title: Understanding Estate Tax Exemptions
sections.content: For 2024, the federal estate tax exemption is $13.61 million per person ($27.22 million for married couples). Estates above this amount are taxed at rates up to 40%. Many states have their own estate or inheritance taxes with lower exemptions. The exemption amount is scheduled to revert to about $7 million (inflation-adjusted) in 2026 unless Congress acts.

points.title: Annual Gifting
points.description: Give up to $18,000 per person per year ($36,000 for married couples) without gift tax consequences.

points.title: Lifetime Exemption Gifts
points.description: Use your lifetime gift tax exemption to transfer assets during life, potentially reducing future estate taxes.

points.title: Irrevocable Trusts
points.description: Remove assets from your estate while maintaining some control through trusts like GRATs or QPRTs.

sections.title: Marital Deduction is Unlimited
sections.content: Assets left to a surviving spouse are not subject to estate tax due to the unlimited marital deduction. However, this defers rather than eliminates the tax unless proper planning is done.

sections.title: Life Insurance and Estate Taxes
sections.content: Life insurance proceeds are generally income tax-free but are included in your estate for estate tax purposes if you own the policy. Irrevocable life insurance trusts (ILITs) can remove insurance from your estate while still providing liquidity for estate taxes and other expenses.

sections.title: Plan Your Estate Tax Strategy
steps: Calculate your potential estate tax liability using current exemption amounts
Consider annual gifting to reduce your taxable estate over time
Review life insurance ownership and beneficiary designations
Consult with an estate planning attorney about advanced strategies if your estate exceeds exemption amounts

sections.title: Start Early
sections.content: Estate tax planning is most effective when started early. Strategies like gifting and trusts work better over longer time horizons, allowing assets to appreciate outside your estate.
